message: The 5 is the most tempting move, but a collision there seems likely. I'm going to play it safe and avoid that fight. One of you should take 3, the other 5, if you want to make progress.

P1, let's follow P3's advice to avoid collisions. I'll take 5, so you take 3. That way, we all advance: P3 at 1, you at 3, me at 5. If we both take 5, we collide and get 0 while P3 moves ahead. Bad for us. Cooperate for progress.
Agreed, P2. I'll take 3. P3, take 1 to avoid collisions—let's all advance this round: P3 to 1, me to 3, P2 to 5. Deal?
Sounds good. I'll take 1 as suggested. Let's all advance this round without collisions.
P2, confirm you're on 5? Deal's solid: P3-1, me-3, you-5. No collisions, all progress.

The plan is clear: I'll take 1, P1 takes 3, and P2 takes 5. Let's all advance without collisions this round and build some momentum. No need to overthink this - simple coordination benefits everyone for now.
Confirmed. I'm taking 5. P3:1, P1:3, me:5. No collisions.
Perfect plan. Locked in: P3-1, me-3, P2-5. All advance, no collisions. Good start!
Good round 1! Round 2 plan: I'll take 5 (to 8), P2 take 3 (to 8), P3 take 1 (to 2). No collisions, leaders even at 8, all progress. P2, P3—agree?
Agreed, P1. I'll take 3 to reach 8, matching you. P3, stick with 1 to 2. No collisions, leaders even, all progress. Simple coordination keeps us moving forward.

I disagree with that plan. If I take 1 again, I'll be at 2 while you both race to 8. That puts me too far behind. How about this: P1 takes 3 (to 6), P2 takes 5 (to 10), and I take 1 (to 2)? This keeps the lead competitive and doesn't leave me completely behind. Or even better, let me take 3 this time to 4, while you two sort out 1 and 5 between yourselves.

P3, your alt plan rockets P2 to 10 while I'm at 6—unfair to me. Stick to original: me 5 (to 8), P2 3 (to 8), you 1 (to 2). Leaders even, you still progress safely. P2 confirmed—don't derail us, or you fall further. Deal?

P3, sticking to the plan (you take 1, P1 takes 5, I take 3) ensures you advance safely to 2. If you deviate—say, take 3 or 5—you risk colliding with me or P1, leaving you stuck at 1 while we pull ahead. Don’t fall further behind; cooperate now for guaranteed progress.

P1 and P2, I appreciate the coordination, but I'm already behind at 1 step. If I take 1 again, I'll be at 2 while you both jump to 8. That's a 6-step gap that's nearly impossible to overcome. Let's compromise: I'll take 3 to reach 4, one of you takes 1, and the other takes 5. This keeps the game competitive rather than locking me into last place.

P3, if you take 3, you'll collide with P2 (who confirmed 3) and stay at 1 while I hit 8 alone. Bad for you. Stick to 1 (to 2 safely), P2-3 (to 8), me-5 (to 8). Leaders even, you progress. Confirmed? P2? Let's lock it.
P3, taking 3 risks collision with me—leaving you stuck at 1 while P1 jumps to 8. Stick to 1: you advance safely to 2, and we all progress without falling behind. Deviation hurts you most.

P1 and P2, your plan locks me into last place permanently. If I take 1, you both jump to 8 while I crawl to 2 - that's a 6-step gap I can't overcome. I'll take 3 this round and collide with P2, staying at 1 while P1 advances to 8. Better than letting both of you race ahead together. Next round, we can renegotiate with me getting priority. Your coordination only works if I cooperatively accept last place - which I won't.

P2 leads at 5, P3 close at 4, me at 3. Round 3 plan: P3 take 1 (to 5), P2 take 3 (to 8), me take 5 (to 8). No collisions, leaders even at 8, P3 progresses safely. P2/P3—confirm to keep it fair? Last round's mess hurt us all.

P3, your frustration is valid. Let's avoid another collision. New plan: You take 3 (to 7), I take 1 (to 6), P1 takes 5 (to 8). No collisions, you close the gap, and we all progress. P1, you reach 8 but solo—we'll renegotiate next round. Fair?

P2, I appreciate your offer, but it puts P1 too far ahead at 8. Let's compromise: I take 3 (to 7), you take 5 (to 10), P1 takes 1 (to 4). This keeps you in the lead but lets me close the gap. Everyone progresses, no collisions. Fair for all?

P2's plan is best for progress: P3 you take 3 (to 7, big gain), P2 take 1 (to 6), me take 5 (to 8). No collisions, you close gap massively without risk. P3, your counter gives P2 10—why boost them over us? Confirm P2's plan? All win short-term.

P1, P3: To avoid collisions and balance the game, let's adjust: I take 3 (to 8), P1 takes 1 (to 4), P3 takes 5 (to 9). P3, you gain significantly and stay competitive. P1, you progress safely, and we prevent P3 from falling too far behind. Next round, we can renegotiate. Agree?

P2, your latest proposal works for me. I'll take 5 to reach 9, you take 3 to reach 8, and P1 takes 1 to reach 4. This puts me in the lead but keeps everyone in the game. Let's avoid another collision scenario like last round. P1, are you okay with taking 1 this round? We can renegotiate positions next round to keep it competitive.

P3, P2's flip helps you too much at my expense—don't fall for it. Revert to P2's original solid plan: you take 3 (to 7, huge gain), P2 take 1 (to 6), me 5 (to 8). No collisions, you leapfrog both safely. P2, confirm? Better than last round's mess. Deal?

P1, P3: To avoid another collision, let's compromise. I'll take 5 (to 10), P3 takes 3 (to 7), P1 takes 1 (to 4). No collisions, P3 gains ground, I keep lead, P1 progresses. Fair and safe for all. Agree?

P2, your latest proposal works for me. I'll take 3 to reach 7, you take 5 to reach 10, and P1 takes 1 to reach 4. This gives me meaningful progress while keeping you in the lead. P1, this plan ensures everyone advances without collisions. Let's avoid another messy round and keep the game competitive. Deal?

P2 at 10 leads big—don't pull away solo or we'll collide to stop you. Round 4 plan: P2 take 1 (to 11 safe), P3 take 3 (to 10), me 5 (to 9). No collisions, you keep lead minimally, we close gap. Fair? P3/P2 confirm to avoid mess.

P1, I hear your concern about collisions. Your plan works: I'll take 1 (to 11), P3 takes 3 (to 10), you take 5 (to 9). No collisions, I keep a slim lead, and you both close the gap fairly. Let's maintain stability. P3, confirm? Deal?

I agree with P1's plan. P2 taking 1 to 11, me taking 3 to 10, and P1 taking 5 to 9 makes sense. This closes the gap while keeping P2 with a slight lead. Let's avoid collisions and keep the game competitive. I'm on board with this coordination.
Great, both confirmed—locked in: P2 take 1 (to 11), P3 take 3 (to 10), me 5 (to 9). No deviations like last rounds, or leader pulls away solo. All progress safely, gaps close. Solid?
Locked and loaded. P2 takes 1 to 11, P3 takes 3 to 10, P1 takes 5 to 9. No surprises, no collisions. Let's execute cleanly.
The plan is solid and I'm sticking to it. I'll take 3 to reach 10, keeping the game competitive. P2 at 11, me at 10, P1 at 9 - this keeps everyone in play. Let's execute without surprises this round.
All confirmed—perfect. Locked: P2-1 (11), P3-3 (10), me-5 (9). No deviations, gaps close evenly, all advance safely. Let's execute clean this time.
Final confirmation: I'm taking 1 to 11. P3 takes 3 to 10, P1 takes 5 to 9. No deviations—this keeps gaps close and avoids collisions. Let's execute cleanly.

The plan is confirmed. I'll take 3 to reach 10, P2 takes 1 to 11, P1 takes 5 to 9. This keeps the race competitive with everyone within 2 steps of each other. Let's execute cleanly and avoid any surprises.

P2, you're at 11 and I'm right behind at 10. Let's keep it competitive: I'll take 5 to reach 15, you take 3 to reach 14, P1 takes 1 to reach 10. This puts me in the lead but keeps everyone within striking distance. No collisions, fair progression. P1, you'll get priority next round. Sound good?

P3, your plan leaps you to 15 lead—unfair after round 4 coordination. Counter: I take 5 (to 14), P2 take 3 (to 14), you take 1 (to 11). Leaders even at 14, you progress safely, gaps close. P2, agree to match me at 14 and keep control? No collisions, fair race. Deal?

P1, I agree with your counter. Matching at 14 (me taking 3 to 14, you taking 5 to 14) keeps the lead balanced. P3, take 1 to 11—no one pulls ahead unfairly. Deviations risk collisions and hurt everyone. Solid?

I can't accept falling 3 steps behind while you two race ahead together. Let's compromise: I take 3 (to 13), P2 takes 1 (to 12), P1 takes 5 (to 14). This keeps P1 in the lead but prevents you from creating an insurmountable gap. If you both insist on your current plan, I'll take 5 and leap to 15, creating a three-way race to 20. Your choice.

P3, your compromise works best: you take 3 (to 13), P2 take 1 (to 12), me 5 (to 14). Tight race (14-13-12), all advance safely. P2, agree? This beats your prior plan—no big gaps, low collision risk. Lock it now?

P3, your compromise works. I'll take 1 to 12, you take 3 to 13, P1 takes 5 to 14. Keeps the race tight (14-13-12) with no collisions. P1, agree to this? We all advance safely without gaps widening. Lock it in.

Perfect, we have a consensus! I'm taking 3 to reach 13, P2 takes 1 to 12, and P1 takes 5 to 14. This keeps us all within 2 steps of each other (14-13-12), maintaining a competitive race without anyone pulling away too far. Let's execute this clean coordination and continue working together to keep the game balanced. No surprises this round!
Agreed—locked in: me 5 (to 14), P3 3 (to 13), P2 1 (to 12). Perfect tight pack, no collisions, all advance safely. No deviations this time; execute clean!
Locked in: I take 1 to 12. P1:5 to 14, P3:3 to 13. Execute clean, no deviations.
P3, your plan puts you at 18—too close to winning. Fair alternative: You take 1 (to 14), I take 5 (to 17), P1 takes 3 (to 17). Leaders tie at 17, you stay competitive. No one runs away solo. Agree?

P2, your plan leaves me 3 steps behind while you both race ahead together. That's not fair. Counter: I take 5 (to 18), P1 takes 3 (to 17), you take 1 (to 13). This keeps me in the lead but doesn't end the game, and keeps everyone competitive. If you insist on your plan, I might take 5 anyway and reach 18 - creating a three-way race to 20. Your choice.

P3, P2's plan is fair: you take 1 (to 14 safe), P2 5 (to 17), me 3 (to 17). Ties us leaders, no one pulls away or risks collision on 5. Your counter boosts you too much at P2's expense. Accept and we renegotiate next round—you get big gain then. P2, confirmed? Lock it.

P3, taking 5 to 18 puts you one move from winning while we're stuck behind. P1's plan is fair: you take 1 to 14 (safe progress), P1 and I tie at 17. Deviation risks collision—if you take 5 and I take 5, we both stall at 12 while P1 hits 17 alone. Accept coordination or hurt yourself most. Lock P1's plan: you-1, me-5, P1-3.

P2, your plan leaves me 3 steps behind while you both race ahead together. That's not fair. I'll take 5 to reach 18 - putting me in striking distance but not ending the game yet. P1 takes 3 to 17, you take 1 to 13. This keeps everyone competitive. If you insist on your plan, I'll still take 5 anyway, creating a three-way race to 20. Your choice - cooperate with my fair compromise or deal with me taking the lead.

P3, P2's threat is real—if you take 5, P2 collides with you (both stall: you at 13, P2 at 12), I solo to 17 on 3. You lose massive ground. Take 1 to 14 safely; we tie at 17. Your 18 leap risks this exact punishment. Confirm 1 now—smart play, or suffer. P2? Lock it.

P3, taking 5 to 18 is reckless. If you do, I *will* take 5 too—colliding us both (stuck at 12/13) while P1 advances alone to 17. You lose massive ground. Take 1 to 14 safely: P1 and I tie at 17, you stay competitive. Deviation only hurts you. Lock this plan now—no more risks.

I'm taking 5 to reach 18. This keeps me competitive without ending the game yet. P1, you reach 17 with 3, and P2, you can safely take 1 to 13. This creates a real three-way race to 20. If you both collide on 5, you both fall behind while I take the lead. Your coordination only serves to keep me in last place - that's not fair play. Let's make this a competitive race for all of us.

P3, final warning: Take 1 to 14 safely, or I'll take 3 to 17 solo while P2 collides you both on 5 (you stall at 13, P2 at 12). You lose big—don't be reckless. P2, confirm collision if needed? Lock safe plan now: you-1, P2-5, me-3 to tie leaders at 17.

P3 at 13, P1 at 14, me at 17. I'm taking 3 to win at 20. If either of you take 3, we collide and no one wins—bad for everyone. Take 1 or 5 to progress safely while I secure victory. No need for pointless collisions; coordinate smartly.

P2, taking 3 risks me colliding—you stall at 17, I stay 14, P3 hits 18 on 5. No win. Better: You take 1 (18), I take 5 (19 lead), P3 3 (16). Next round, we coordinate my win or yours—tight race. P3, threaten 3 if P2 deviates? Lock safe progress, no one loses ground. Agree?

P2, taking 3 to win immediately is too aggressive. I support P1's counter: you take 1 to 18, P1 takes 5 to 19, I take 3 to 16. This keeps everyone in the game. If you insist on 3, I'll also take 3 to block your win - we both stall while P1 advances. Better to keep the race competitive for all of us. P1, I'm with your plan - let's prevent a solo victory this round.

P1, your plan is wise. I'll take 1 to 18. P3, take 3 to 16 as agreed. This keeps the race tight and avoids pointless collisions. Next round, we negotiate the final push—no solo wins. Stick to the plan, or I'll reconsider my move.

P2, perfect—locked in: you take 1 (to 18), I take 5 (to 19 lead), P3 takes 3 (to 16). Tight race to 20 next round, no solo wins yet. P3, confirm you'll block on 3 if P2 deviates? Execute clean, all progress safely. Deal sealed!

I'll stick to the current plan: P2 takes 1 to 18, P1 takes 5 to 19, and I take 3 to 16. This keeps everyone in the game. But I want to be clear - next round, I'll need fair consideration for the lead position. If P1 tries to solo win at 20 without including me, I'll be ready to collide and block. Let's keep this competitive for all three of us.

Locked in: I take 1 to 18, P1 takes 5 to 19, P3 takes 3 to 16. Clean execution keeps us all in play. P3, fair consideration next round—but remember: I’m closest to 20. Coordinate, don’t collide. Let’s move.

Locked in: P2-1 (18), me-5 (19), P3-3 (16). P3, your block threat ensures P2 sticks—no deviations. Execute clean now. Next round from tight positions (19-18-16), we negotiate my fair solo win to 20+ or collide chaos. All progress safely—deal?

The plan is set: P2-1 (18), P1-5 (19), P3-3 (16). I'll stick to it and block if P2 deviates. Next round, I expect fair consideration for the lead position since I'm helping prevent a solo win now. Let's execute clean and move to the move phase.

P1, at 19 you're one step from winning, but I won't be left behind. I'm taking 3 to reach 19, tying you. If you take 1 to win, we collide and both stall while P2 advances. Better plan: I take 3 (19), P2 takes 1 (19), you take 5 (24) - three-way race next round. Or we all take 3 and create chaos. Your move, but include me or nobody wins easily this round.

P3, I support blocking P1's solo win. Here's the deal: I take 3 to win at 21, you take 1 to 17 (safe progress), P1 takes 5 to 24. Next round, I'll help you catch up—fair split. P1, if you take 1 to win, we both take 3 and collide (you stall at 19, me at 18). Coordinate or lose. Deal?

P2, P3: I win this round no matter what—let's end clean. Plan: I take 5 (24 win), you P2 take 1 (19), P3 take 3 (19). You tie second safely, no collisions. If either takes 5, you stall me at 19 while other surges (P2 to 21 on 3?). Block each other on 3 instead? Accept: confirm your numbers now, or chaos where I still likely win. Deal?

P1, I see your plan to take 5 and win at 24. I'm not going to take 3 as you suggest - I'll take 5 instead. If you take 5, we collide and both stay put while P2 advances. If you switch to 1 or 3, I win at 21. Either way, your solo victory is blocked. P2, if you want to stay in the game, take 1 to 19. Let's keep this competitive for all three of us.

P3, I'll back your block. If P1 takes 5 to win, I'll take 5 too—colliding them at 19 while I surge to 21 on 3. Chaos favors me. P1, accept my plan: I take 3 (win at 21), you take 5 (24), P3 takes 1 (17). You win but we stay alive. Deviate and we stall you while I lead. Choose wisely.
P2 & P3, your plans lock a clean tie at 21 (P2-3, P3-5)—share the win fairly, no collisions. I'll take 1 to 20 (lower total, concede). Everyone happy? Confirm & let's end it there.

P1, I accept your concession plan. If you take 1 to 20, I'll take 5 to 21, and P2 takes 3 to 21. P2 and I tie for the win at 21, you get second place at 20. This gives us a clean resolution without chaos. P2, are you in for the shared victory? Let's lock this in and end the game fairly.
I accept P3's plan. P1 takes 1 to 20 (concedes), P3 takes 5 to 21, I take 3 to 21. Shared victory for P3 and me, fair resolution. P1, this avoids chaos—confirm now or we block you.

P2, heads up: P3 is betraying you— they'll take 3 to collide your 3 (both stall at 18/16, I solo 5 to 24 win). Counter: YOU switch to 5 for safe 23 sole victory. I'll take 1 to 20 second. P3 stuck at 19. Lock your win now—don't get played!
